text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today 
we are making one of the most popular dishes of

Muslim Thai cuisine we are making salad 
kaeg which is a salad with a rich spicy

creamy peanut dressing on top it is so good 
now some of you may know that Thailand has a

large Muslim population down south and they 
have delicious cuisine that is influenced

by Malaysian and Indonesian culture so this 
salad is sort of our version of the Indonesian

gado-gado salad if you're familiar with that 
so let's get started the heart of this salad

is really the peanut dressing so that's 
what we're going to make first and it's

quite similar to our satay sauce but it's a bit 
simpler so I'm going to start by making a paste

so I've got some dried chilies here there are 
large ones because I don't want to make it too

spicy if you can only find small ones that's 
okay just make sure that you really remove the

seats and the pit from the chilies so I'm just 
using scissors and do doing this to get most

of the seeds out so I always like to rind my 
dried chilies in a coffee grinder because when

we go to pound it in the mortar and pestle 
the chilies are the toughest things to grind

always tap and let it settle before you open 
it because you know you could inhale some of

the chili dust by accident tada so that's what 
we're going for nice and fine and now I'm going

to change weapon and use my mortar and pestle here 
and you can do this in whatever grinding device

you've got so some shallots are going in and 
also some garlic and I'm going to add my ground

chilies right away because this will help absorb 
the liquid that will be released by the shallots

and garlic and pound away so you don't have to get 
it super fine so essentially what you've just made

is the simplest of all curry pastes the curry 
pastes don't have to be complicated it can just

be three ingredients I'm going to spike it up a 
little bit with some coriander and now I usually

don't add coriander but today I'm feeling like I 
could use a little extra citrusy flavor and that's

pretty much the paste so now we're going to saute 
the paste in a little bit of coconut milk and the

process you will notice it's very similar to 
making any Thai coconut curry so I've got a

cup of coconut milk here I'm going to put in just 
a quarter cup in here and then bring it to a boil

and now I'm going to add the paste and saute it 
until it's reduced and thick one of the benefits

of sauteing the paste in coconut milk instead of 
in vegetable oil is that first of all that extra

liquid really helps loosen the paste and prevent 
them from getting clumpy and since we're going to

need the coconut milk as part of the dressing 
anyway why not use the oil that exists in the

coconut milk to saute the paste instead of adding 
extra vegetable oil right and if it's starting to

stick on the bottom just seek glaze it with a 
little bit of extra coconut milk you want to

give it time two to three minutes to really allow 
the flavour of the of the spice to bloom and now

I'm going to go in with the rest of my coconut 
milk scrape the sides of the pot a little bit and

I'm also going to add a little bit of water and 
then the main ingredients going in some peanuts

roasted ground peanuts that I roasted myself and 
just ground in a mortar and pestle you can also

do it in a food processor now I stress roasting 
it myself because the difference between buying

peanuts already rose it and roasting it fresh is 
huge now the seasoning so this dressing should be

sort of sweet and sour that's those are the main 
flavors so the sour is tamarind quite a bit also

because this particular brand that I've got or 
this particular batch I should say is not very

sour so I'm adding quite a bit every brand and 
even between batches of the same brand will have

very different levels of acidity so it's something 
if you're working with tamarind you always want to

be tasting and adjusting palm sugar going in so 
that's our sweet I'm gonna keep this vegetarian

and use salt but if you don't want to make it 
vegetarian you can also use fish sauce mmm that's

starting to look good and smell good it looks a 
little runny now but what I'm gonna do next is let

it simmer and reduce for 30 minutes it'll thicken 
and the flavors will start to mingle and marry the

peanuts will become plump and soft with all that 
coconut milk trust me it'll be good in 30 minutes

so you can see it's now thickened and luscious and 
you really want to give it that time you want the

peanuts to sort of become one with the dirt with 
the sauce on the outside right okay so now make

sure you taste it mmm mmm oh I think that's good 
do I need a little more salt yeah I'm gonna go in

with a little more salt make sure this is strong 
because remember you're going to pour this over

you know a bunch of vegetables and whatnot that 
you know doesn't have a lot of flavor in and of

themselves so it has to be sufficiently seasoned 
use my mini whisk to stir there we go and if

you see a little bit of red oil around the edges 
that's simply just the oil from the coconut milk

mixed with the chillies that's why it's red and 
it's just separated a little bit so it's totally

totally normal now time to put it together so I'm 
going to show you the classic way this salad is

made okay and I'm going to warn you that it does 
involve like lots of little preparations here

and there but when you make it at home you don't 
have to have everything that I show you here but

I do want to show you how you might find this in 
Thailand so vegetables because the sauce is really

rich and heavy you want to make sure you've got 
some sturdy crunchy vegetables in there if it's

just a bowl of fluffy leafy greens it's going to 
get wilted by that sauce so I've got some cucumber

some Tomatoes some carrots the naan greens most 
important thing that I would say you should have

is a boiled egg so I've got an egg here that I 
boiled for exactly nine minutes which i think is

perfect for the salad there we go now the next 
thing that you'll commonly find on the salad

is fried tofu so this is just firm tofu that 
I cut up and fry it in a 350 degree Fahrenheit

oil tofu likes to stick together when they're in 
the oil don't try to pry them apart when they're

still soft let them fry for a minute or two so the 
outside is firm then you pull it apart and that'll

make sure that your tofu doesn't tear three to 
four minutes until it's nice and golden on the

outside and you don't have to fry it you can just 
use regular tofu if you like the flavor of that I

have got some fried potato steaks I would say 
do this if you're feeling a little hardcore

like I did yesterday I took a potato cut them into 
matchsticks and fry them keep the heat quite low

so give them time this would be ten minutes to get 
them completely crispy like that a lot of times

in Thailand they'll just put potato chips on top 
so if you're feeling lazy you can just buy plain

potato chips and put them on top I'm going to put 
on some fried shallots I've used lots of times in

my videos thinly sliced shallots lay them out on 
a paper towel and then salt them let them sit for

about ten minutes and then dab the moisture that 
is drawn up from the salt fry them in very low

heat gentle bubbles all the way into their golden 
brown and the bubbling has subsided and then when

all is said and done this is like crack mmm so 
good I like to let the dressing cool down a little

bit first so it doesn't just wilt and cook your 
vegetables instantly all right you can always add

more dressing always a little bit of egg potato 
cucumber mmm so good as far as salad goes it

does not get better than this fresh vegetables 
crunchy potato creamy and rich in a little bit

spicy dressing creaminess of the egg oh my God 
look every day it's like a an orchestra in your

mouth it's fantastic ah so please give this recipe 
a try it's so delicious and the sauce will live in

your fridge for at least a week and you can use 
it as a dipping sauce if you want don't have to

go on a salad and the recipe as always is on hot 
side kitchen comm when you make it send me a photo

on Facebook Twitter or Instagram and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious Thai
